Hey, uh, a major component of the science of canning--in which you are using mason jar with the lids--is that the food is stored in a vacuum.  If you don't want to use heat to vacuum seal the jars, you could just use an attachment--like the ones offered by FoodSaver--to vacuum seal the jars.  You didn't need to drill a hole in the mason jar lids.  They're designed to hold a vacuum seal. Also, it's possible that some of that food you tested may have botulism, since the toxin is created from a certain bacteria when put in an anaerobic condition and they weren't properly processed.  Check out any Canning 101 course to see the science behind this already done.

Keeping something vacuum is actually very challenging, especially over such a long period. What you should do is to vacuum these jars EVERY DAY. Otherwise they might be little oxygen for the first few hours/days, but after that they will be no difference between the vacuum jars and non-vacuum jars. What's worse, unlike human beings, bacteria requires very little oxygen, so those vacuum jars prevented food from drying out (because water vapor can't go out), yet it has enough oxygen for bacteria, so it's oxygen + moisture, which is even worse then just oxygen but dry food. That's why you get worse results from apple and bread.

The porous nature of the jar and rubber valve make extended non-continuous vacuum applications impractical. You are going to gradually lose whatever vacuum you have and after 4 weeks enough air will have seeped in that you will have virtually no vacuum. They are literally designed to create a vacuum without the need of making a rubber valve on top.

Sorry but this was a poor test - a rubber flap and tape is NEVER going to make a long term vacuum seal.

1) Put a one way valve with a hose tail in each jar lid.
2) Use t pieces and tubing and connect all jars together - creating a manifold.
3) Run tubing to vaccum pump and in this single tube fit a vacuum switch and a vacuum gauge and wire the switch to the vacuum pump.
4)Turn vacuum pump on and leave for however long for the test.

Due to the switch the vacuum pump will draw air out initially then just cycle on and off occasionally to maintain vacuum loss due to mechanical leakage and off gassing of the food stuffs increasing pressure/adding contamination.
The one way valves help minimise cross contamination between jars.

There's a difference between stale and rotten.
If something turns stale, it absorbs moisture from its surroundings. By putting it into a vacuum, you can prevent that. That's why the dry foods were still okay after the four weeks.
On the other hand, the "wet" foods have rotten, because there was still moisture which microorganisms could use to grow. Only difference was that in a vacuum, there are mostly anaerobic microorganisms instead of aerobic ones.

Here's the scientific answer to save you some time. Food goes stale or rotten when exposed to air or moisture (or bacteria, fungus or mold). There are no particles in the chamber but the food so it can't go stale and it can't rot because there's no oxygen which means any mold, bacteria and fungus can't respire so they die

Edit: Apples are mostly air (which is why they float) so the air can escape the apple when cut into slices. Air is a gas, which is a fluid, so it tries to take up the space of the chamber. Because there is air the mold that is already on the apple when you put it in survives off that air and the moisture in the apple. If the apple was covered in the skin/not cut the air wouldn't be able to escape so it wouldn't grow mold

At 7:26 "It's possible we haven't kept a perfect vacuum on all of these". You're correct in that statement. The drilling/rubber seal idea was unnecessary. It would have been easier and simpler if you just placed the mason jar lids on the jars and put them in the vacuum chamber (without the bands). The pressure inside the mason jar would have lifted the lid enough to allow the vacuum to draw the air out. When the vacuum pump was turned off, the rubber on the lid would have sealed the jar. Then you could place the screw bands on. Check out a FoodSaver wide mouth jar sealer, which works on the same principle.

TLDR: The mason jar lid works on the same exact principle as the rubber + electrical tape, and works better.

I can see you are trying to make a nice scientific experiment, which I wholeheartedly support. However, you have way too many variables going on with this setup to reliably examine if vacuum vs no vacuum results in difference in food quality. I would suggest that :

1- Do not drill holes in the canning jar lids - those lids (Ball/Kerr) have for decades been verified to hold a seal and you are compromising their integrity (and making it harder on yourself) with taping rubber over a hole. Just put the lid on, turn ring to finger-tight (not super tight, you want air to be able to escape), and carry on with vacuum. There are also actual systems already made to create a vacuum seal on canning jars, such as with the foodsaver.

2- To reduce variables in your experiment, keep the non-vacuum samples in the same jars with a lid (finger-tight to let any gases escape), rather than exposed to further airborne contamination or dehydration, as these can drastically affect how the food items also change over time. These controls will still have atmospheric pressure and oxygen exposure even with the lids on.

I can tell you right away you made a few mistakes with your preservation method.   The rubber stopper idea is great, but flawed.   Drilling a hole in the lid makes an irregular opening with microdents and metal burrs; this will impact the seal at a microscopic level.   Also, the jar within a jar evacuation method doesn't allow for 100% of air to be removed.   The moment you release the suction, the pressure balance is restored to all areas of the vacuum chamber.   This floods all areas simultaneously; instantly.   A negligible, yet problematic amount of air will still manage to flow into the inner jar just before the inner seal sets.   My advice would be to do these separately in the vacuum chamber itself to get a true result.

FFR (For Future Reference) There was no need to drill holes, mason jar lids work perfectly the way you intended your valves to work. The rubber gasket on the lid allows air to escape as well as creat a seal to prevent air from getting in. The screw ring is put on loose enough to hold the lid in place, then tightened down after vacuuming. That is how canning works and food can be preserved for a long time. No need to reinvent the wheel.

I use mason jars (ultra clean) with my pair of FoodSaver machines to seal every kind of food. Dry foods are sealed under vacuum in the jars (with the proper fixture designed for Mason jars and no mods to the lids) and will last almost indefinitely. Pasta, grains, nuts and cereals are fine this way for years. Wet foods are best kept sealed under vacuum and refrigerated or frozen and my frozen stuff gets sealed in vacuum bags before going in the freezer.

canning - including jars (Mason Jars, etc) is a long ago preservation technique.
Canning is little more that creating a vacuum with very little air
provided you fill the container almost completely.
Another part of canning is to submerge in fluid.
Apples, okay in fluid, Bread, no.
So apples can be preserved by canning pretty well while bread cannot.

Canning fluid should be high in sugar content or be acidic for best results.
Sugar will not ferment if the ratio is above some percentage (27% ?)

I’m a microbiologist in training and I think I know why the vacuum was disturbed. The answer is not likely that the seals broke or air got in, but more so the microbes and fungus living on the food created their own atmosphere. Many microbial decomposers are anaerobic which means they don’t need oxygen and occasionally don’t even need air to survive. Where you left the unsterile food exposed to unsterile objects, decomposers contaminated the samples and went to work regardless of air pressure. The lack of pressure may have disturbed some of them, but by the looks of it, mostly cells with cell walls survived because the cell wall helps to regulate the cells size and shape, resisting the vacuum chamber. As they broke down the saccharides (sugars) in the food, they created oxygen and carbon dioxide. Also, there could be traces of other gases depending such as nitrogen depending on what parts the microbes and fungus decomposed and what types of metabolisms they use to respire. Water could also be created through respiration which is why the bread may have been even more moist than it was to begin with.

To sum it up, organisms that don’t require air or an atmosphere contaminated your samples and created their own atmosphere within a vacuum chamber.

The two components of successful canning are a negative pressure seal and heat sterilization.

Plants usually release quinones, which volatilizes and oxidizes when their tissues are exposed to air.  It's what makes cut fruit rapidly darken, and also the dark color of most degraded material in soils or composts.  The molecule repels insects in its oxidized state, and serves a role in metabolic processes as an ion.  Clearly it's not as effective a deterrent against fungi.

It looks like the bread in the vacuum was possibly contaminated before going in the chamber. It could have been from a finger, a tiny spot of saliva, from the table or even the jar itself (especially if it was handled without gloves prior to the experiment.) and the retained moisture in the bread created perfect breeding conditions for mold. Plus only one slice showed a lot of mold propagation from one spot (usually bread going moldy has several small propagation spots) is the reason of my suspicions. To get truer results you would need to sterilize everything and use sterile gloves, face-mask to prevent micro spit/saliva spatter while talking.

As a biologist the answer is simple:
If there are any microrganisms which can grow in the storage condition OR one of the food's components can change overtime, the food will become bad.

If you sterilize the food before placing it in a vacuum and it doesn't have any components to change, it remains preserved for years. But applying the vacuum might be a sterilizing process itself.

You really don't need to modify the jars at all to let them store vacuum. Simply remove the twist on jar lid, leaving the metal lid in place. It already has a gasket type material on the lid. Most of the "vacuum packer" units come with jar sealing kits that do the same thing.
